title: 109_hr2936
content: The "Second Opinion Coverage Act of 2005" requires group health plans to cover second opinions under the Public Health Service Act. The "Second Opinion Coverage Act of 2005" mandates group health plans to provide or authorize a second opinion by a qualified healthcare professional when requested by a participant, beneficiary, or enrollee questioning surgical procedures or diagnosis for life-threatening conditions. The "Second Opinion Coverage Act of 2005" requires group health plans to offer a second opinion by a qualified healthcare professional in cases of unclear diagnoses, ineffective treatment plans, or when requested by the participant. The "Second Opinion Coverage Act of 2005" mandates group health plans to provide a second opinion by an appropriately qualified healthcare professional for unclear diagnoses or ineffective treatment plans. The professional must have relevant clinical background and expertise. Opinions must be rendered promptly upon request. The Second Opinion Coverage Act of 2005 requires timely second opinions for participants facing imminent health threats, with a maximum response time of 72 hours. Plans must establish timelines for emergency cases within 90 days of enactment and update them within 30 days of any changes. Timelines must be available to the public upon request. The Second Opinion Coverage Act of 2005 mandates timely second opinions for participants in urgent health situations, with a 72-hour response time limit. Participants are only responsible for copayments for second opinions approved by the group health plan. Primary care second opinions must be provided by a qualified professional within the same physician organization, while specialist second opinions can be requested by the participant. The Second Opinion Coverage Act of 2005 allows participants to request a second opinion from a specialist of their choice within the network, with the plan covering the cost. If no qualified provider is available within the network, the plan must authorize a second opinion from an appropriately qualified outside consultant. The plan or issuer must authorize a second opinion from a qualified health professional outside the network, considering the participant's ability to travel. The second opinion provider must provide a consultation report with recommended procedures, and the plan can authorize additional medical opinions independently. The plan or issuer must notify the participant of denial for a second opinion and provide information on filing a grievance. Services must be obtained from participating providers unless authorized by the plan. Referrals may be limited to the plan's network of providers. The section specifies that health care plans with preferred provider contracts are exempt from certain requirements if second opinions are not limited. Additionally, group health plans must comply with notice requirements under ERISA. Amendments to the ERISA law are also mentioned. ERISA amendments include adding a new section to the law regarding health care plans with preferred provider contracts and notice requirements for group health plans. SEC. 714. COVERAGE OF SECOND OPINIONS. Section 714 of the Act addresses the coverage of second opinions in group health plans and insurance coverage. It requires compliance with section 2707 provisions and treats the requirement as a material modification in the plan, necessitating notice within 60 days of the first plan year to ensure awareness. Additionally, section 731(c) is amended to include references to sections 711 and 714. Section 732(a) of the Act (29 U.S.C. 1191a(a)) is amended by inserting "sections 711 and 714". The table of contents in section 1 of the Act is amended by adding a new item after section 713. Coverage of second opinions is added to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 under section 9813. Coverage of second opinions is included in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 under section 9813, with requirements similar to those in the Public Health Service Act. In the individual market, health insurance coverage must comply with the provisions of section 2707, similar to group health plans. Health insurance issuers must also provide notice as required by the Employee Retirement Income Security Act. Section 2762(b)(2) is amended to include additional sections. Effective dates apply to group health plans and insurance. Effective dates for the amendments made to group health plans and group health insurance coverage start on January 1, 2006. For individual health insurance coverage, the amendments apply to plans offered, sold, issued, renewed, or operated in the individual market on or after that date, with an exception for group health plans under collective bargaining agreements. The amendments to group health plans and insurance coverage are effective starting January 1, 2006. The Secretaries of Labor, Treasury, and Health and Human Services will coordinate administration through an interagency memorandum of understanding. The Secretaries of Labor, Treasury, and Health and Human Services will coordinate regulations and enforcement policies to ensure consistency and avoid duplication of efforts.
